concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! Welcome to our session. I'm here to listen and support you, so feel free to share anything that's on your mind.
Hey, thanks for having me. I've just been feeling overwhelmed lately with everything going on in my life.
Therapist: It sounds like there's a lot weighing on you right now. What's been feeling the most overwhelming for you lately?
client: I guess it's the uncertainty about my future, especially with career and immigration stuff. It feels like I'm running out of time and options.
That sounds incredibly challenging and stressful. What would life look like for you if some of these uncertainties were resolved?
I think I'd feel a lot more at ease and confident about my future. Like, I'd have a clear path and wouldn't constantly worry about having to leave or not finding a stable job.
It sounds like having stability and clarity would really enhance your peace of mind and confidence. What steps do you think might move you closer to that sense of ease and clarity?

Honestly, figuring out a way to further my education seems like a big step. Maybe exploring more realistic pathways to get a Master's or building up my skills in areas that'd help my career goals could help.

Based on what you've shared, exploring educational opportunities or skill-building pathways seems like key steps. How does setting a goal around researching Master's programs or identifying skill-building resources sound to you? What might be a first action step toward this goal?

client: I think setting a goal around researching Master's programs is a good idea. Maybe my first step could be looking into online courses or community college classes to strengthen my math and coding skills.

That sounds like a solid plan. By starting with online courses or community college classes, you're taking a practical step towards your goal. What are some potential barriers you might encounter, and how do you think you could address them?
I guess time and money could be big barriers. I might worry about balancing work with studying, and the costs of additional classes might be a bit much right now.

It sounds like you're thoughtfully considering the challenges ahead. One option could be looking into scholarships or financial aid for those classes, and for time management, maybe setting a specific study schedule could help. How do these ideas resonate with you, or do you have other thoughts on managing these barriers?

I think the idea of looking into scholarships or financial aid is definitely a good route. As for time management, setting a study schedule could be useful, but I'm a bit worried about sticking to it with everything else going on.

You've done a fantastic job identifying ways to address the barriers of time and finances, which shows you're really committed to moving forward. Looking into scholarships and financial aid is a proactive step, and setting a study schedule might provide some structure to help manage your time. It's completely understandable to feel concerned about sticking to it with your current workload. Perhaps starting with small, manageable time blocks might make it feel less overwhelming. Remember, you're taking important steps toward clarity and stability, and each small action counts. Keep exploring those opportunities and reach out anytime you need to talk through any challenges or need support. You've got this!
Thanks, I appreciate the support. I'll definitely try to break it into smaller time blocks and see how it goes.
